_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In this wastewater treatment facility, we handle chlorine, which is considered hazardous by EPA. The same properties that make chlorine vauable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling chlorine to prevent unneccesary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our own personal health as well as that of our co-worker and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine.  The safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel

Our emergency response program is based upon the facilitie's chlorine Standard Operating and Emergency Procedures and Indian River County Emergency Plan For Hazardous Materials.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.

The stationary source and regulated substance handled.
The primary purpose of this facility is to treat wastewater from the surrounding community.  Chlorine is used during the treatment process primarily to disinfect the effluent.  Chlorine is received by semi truck and unloaded by stationary crane.  The crane is load tested yearly by certified personnel.  The chlorine storage room only has access by authorized personnel.  The total inventory of chlorine stored at this plant is 10,000 pounds.

The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenarios(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario.
Worst-Case Scenario:  Failure of 2-1 ton cylinders of chlorine with a release of 4,000 pounds of chlorine.  It is assumed that the entire contents are released as vapor, which is heavier than air.

Alternative Release Scenario: A vacuum line break.
The general accidental release

prevention program and the specific prevention steps.
This wastewater treatment facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and all applicable State codes and regulations.  This facility is operated in accordance with recommendations from the Chlorine Institute.

Five year accident history.
No accidental releases of chlorine occurred during the last five years.

The emergency response program.
This facility's emergency response program is based upon the plants Standard Operating and Emergency Procedures and Indian River County Emergency Plan for Hazardous Materials.  Indian River County Fire Department has performed a release drill on a one-ton cylinder on February 23, 1999.

Planned changes to improve safety.
This facility was constructed in 1986 and upgraded in 1996 and is in compliance with Chlorine Institute guidelines.  We continue to participate in the Chlorine Institute programs and continue to improve our operations in accordance with RMP.
